Summary Electromechanical Technician with 10 years of experience in a multinational high-tech company with an electronics technician and studies in Information Systems Engineering. Extensive experience in Manufacturing, Maintenance and Customer Service. Pneumatic knowledge, safety, quality, lean manufacturing, coordination skills and training of personnel and introduction of new products. High analytical thinking methodically focused on the tasks and foster an environment of stable and harmonious work. 
 
I am experienced and trained in functions associated with all Manufacturing Floor including operations, equipment, processing and training. My responsibilities in the past include collecting and evaluating operating data to conduct on-line equipment adjustment while ensuring process optimization. I was fully responsible for running lots in a qualitative way. Also, responsible for preventive maintenance, troubleshooting, spares, and sustainability. In addition, I was responsible for improving processes, troubleshooting nonstandard events in the production line, and reviewing technological health and stability. I am qualified for the buddy, trainer, and certifier levels and in the past I have been in charge of updating training manuals. My tasks and job title has been multifaceted and complex. In result I worked within the spectrum ranging from narrowly defined parameters with limited judgment up to highly complex and nonstandard assignments in nature. High degree of judgment and initiative was essential in resolving complex nonstandard problems and developing recommendations. I commonly received general instructions on routine work, and detailed instructions on new work. Experience Senior Manufacturing Technician Intel Corporation May 2005  –  May 2015  (10 years 1 month) Costa Rica My responsibilities include collecting and evaluating operating data to conduct on-line equipment adjustment while ensuring process optimization. I was fully responsible for running lots in a qualitative way. Also, responsible for preventive maintenance, troubleshooting, spares, and sustainability. In addition, I was responsible for improving processes, troubleshooting nonstandard events in the production line, and reviewing technological health and stability. 
 
• Contributed in the stabilization process and maintenance of equipment, analyzing trends in transferring equipment and simple techniques and methods so that a growth in the availability of equipment from 77% to 93% was achieved without impacting commitments production. 
• Directed and coordinated the coaching area and equipment preventive maintenance, organizing tasks, encouraging the skills and abilities of the companions and prioritizing requirements. The performance of equipment 80% to 87% increased. 
• Led conversions products manufacturing equipment, organizing the times and the methods and materials planning early. Conversion time 6 to 3 hours is decreased and loss of product quality problems are prevented. 
 
 Senior Manufacturing Technician Intel Corporation June 2014  –  March 2015  (10 months) Ho Chi Minh, Vietnam I supported the start-up of new production line in Vietnam's Factory, trained and pass down my knowledge to new technicians, I worked on tools installation and qualification, where I achieved records numbers in productivity, safety and quality. 
 
• Plan the training of Vietnamese technical personnel in new manufacturing equipment, material designing, optimizing content and training to reviewers. 80% of qualified people and training time 5-3 days decreased was obtained. 
• Assist in the transfer of goods from Costa Rica to Vietnam, as well as process optimization, installing equipment and simplifying the tasks. A reduction was obtained at the time of installation and qualification systems 4-2 weeks without negative impact on quality.

Summary Hello, thank you very much for reading my Bio. 
 
I am full time employed as a technician, Operating and fixing machines in a high volume manufacturing facility, high-vacuum plasma environment. I'm in my current position 18yrs.  
 
I am married, with children and along with work and home-DIY, the pursuit of running to maintain fitness and never become complacent in life....  
Photography, by default is in the 3rd or 4th seat of interests. 
 
Photography is a part time love affair. 
My Passion is photography. I'm good at it - but I will always be trying to get better. 
 
Photography for me is recording memories or images that tell stories. In short, I would describe myself in photography as a people watcher, watching for quirks or emotions at 'that moment'. 
I do not do invasive-paparazzi type images. Don't ask me to. 
 
My by-line is : "Telling some of life's stories through images". 
 
When I do agree or commit to a project - I do stay the course and am totally sincere and honest in my dealings. Outside of agreed projects - what free time is spent exploring the streets and sights of Dublin and it's surrounds. 
Occasionally, if an image that could cause embarrassment to the subject, arrives through my lens. That's OK, I choose not to publish them. That's my choice. 
Life is there to be fun in, not to be made fun of.  
 
I also choose NOT to be on Facebook - please don't invite me.  
 
All that said. Allow me to change my mind and update my bio as I develop thoughts and ideas through my images. Summary Hello, thank you very much for reading my Bio.

Hi-Vacuum, Plasma, and PVD systems. 
Shift based, 12hr rotating Nights/Days and also front/Back end week. 
 
In short, you never know what time of day or night you might find me responding to tool alarms or emails. 
 
"No matter how complex the machine, it's still only nut, bolts and wires - with a bit of magic thrown in" Volunteer Photographer, Media Team Triathlon Ireland April 2012  – Present (3 years 5 months) Island of Ireland Volunteer Media team member with Triathlon Ireland, the National governing body for Triathlon and related sports in Ireland  Machinery installation fitter, logistics transport Elenco Engineering Co. October 1996  –  June 1997  (9 months) Dublin, Ireland Again on the road, seeing the country. 
To sum up: I was a machinery installation fitter. My Duties were on-site survey, machinery decommission, removal from premises, transport logistics to new destination. Installation on new premises and assisting commissioning of installed toolsets. 
Depending on contract, some or all, of above component parts of an operation. 
 
Was I on my own ? No - not a chance. We were a small crew, the riggers, having been in the business a longer time knew their roles very well and were safe - very safe in their work. An abiding memory of the time was their motto: "A 10-Tonne machine don't bounce" ! 
 
I was responsible for the dismantling and re-assembling of machinery I had never seen before, so every contract was a learning, often difficult but never dull ! Transport Driver and Logistics Capital Stone, Dublin July 1996  –  September 1996  (3 months) Dublin, Ireland Back on home soil, recovered form Malaria - Yes, Africa finally caught me and in my last weeks too. 
You've got to keep moving, doing something.  
It's alright saying - I was there, it's better saying I am here ! 
 
Logistical planning and transportation of granite and marble source material and finished product from a Dublin central location to throughout Ireland. Occasionally from Britain also. 
 
I enjoyed this job, not my norm - something different, a good way to settle back home ! Field service officer United Nations October 1994  –  June 1996  (1 year 9 months) Kigali, Rwanda Accepting a position as FSO in the UN was a major milestone. Similar to previous positions with regard to the logistical setup, maintenance and repair of electrical generating equipment throughout the country. Eventually in the withdrawal of the UN mission, assisting the convoy out through Uganda into Kenya. 
The Genocide in Rwanda was only months in passing before my station, people still were in trauma and yet the country still needed to operate on a basic level.  
A beautifully picturesque land and people. And like Liberia, a troubled past. Technical, volunteer United Nations April 1994  –  October 1994  (7 months) Liberia, West Africa Fleet service technican, Garage organisation and management. Convoy support and Logistics. 
Based in capital Monrovia. Involved with the daily support of fleet maintenance.  
Specialist skills included the logistical and physical support of vehicle convoys incoming from C'ote D'Ivoir. Retrieval of damaged vehicles also, in particular under duress of hostile fire. 
Some French language skill (lowkey). 
 
Liberia in west Africa was under the grip of a Civil war, with Charles Taylor on one side and local Government on the other..  
It's rich political history from the freeing and repatriation of slaves, to the worlds largest rubber plantation.  
Images from here are fewer due to the hostile activities, but if you wish to read more, please read here: http://www.un.org/en/peacekeeping/missions/unmil/background.shtml Technical, Volunteer United Nations January 1993  –  January 1994  (1 year 1 month) Cambodia A year in South-East Asia.  
Jealous - You should be - a remarkable land, and remarkable people. 
Have a read: http://www.un.org/en/peacekeeping/missions/past/untacbackgr1.html 
 
My role in supporting the UN mission was in the logistical setup, maintenance and repair of electrical generating equipment throughout the northwest region of Cambodia, to allow the electoral officers run the first free and democratic elections in a country that had undergone a massive social and political change through War and Dictatorship. 
 
Throughout the mission, I always carried a camera (Film) - and some of the most memorable images I have ever taken are from here. Technical Staff Member British Antarctic Survey November 1990  –  April 1992  (1 year 6 months) Antarctica Overwintering in the Antarctic. Straight from my apprenticeship to support the life systems generators on science base with the BAS.
